title: Life Expectancy and Population
text:
Life Expectancy and Population
This page explores the relationship between life expectancy and population (in millions) from the Gapminder dataset. The scatter plot below colors points by continent.

# Load required libraries
library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)


Attaching package: 'dplyr'


The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':

    filter, lag


The following objects are masked from 'package:base':

    intersect, setdiff, setequal, union

library(readr)

# Read the CSV file using read_csv
gapminder <- read_csv("D:/QTM530/qtm350-quiz02/gapminder.csv")

Rows: 1704 Columns: 6


── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr (2): country, continent
dbl (4): year, life_expectancy, population_millions, gdp_per_capita

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

# Inspect the data structure
str(gapminder)

spc_tbl_ [1,704 × 6] (S3: spec_tbl_df/tbl_df/tbl/data.frame)
 $ country            : chr [1:1704] "Afghanistan" "Afghanistan" "Afghanistan" "Afghanistan" ...
 $ continent          : chr [1:1704] "Asia" "Asia" "Asia" "Asia" ...
 $ year               : num [1:1704] 1952 1957 1962 1967 1972 ...
 $ life_expectancy    : num [1:1704] 28.8 30.3 32 34 36.1 ...
 $ population_millions: num [1:1704] 8.43 9.24 10.27 11.54 13.08 ...
 $ gdp_per_capita     : num [1:1704] 779 821 853 836 740 ...
 - attr(*, "spec")=
  .. cols(
  ..   country = col_character(),
  ..   continent = col_character(),
  ..   year = col_double(),
  ..   life_expectancy = col_double(),
  ..   population_millions = col_double(),
  ..   gdp_per_capita = col_double()
  .. )
 - attr(*, "problems")=<externalptr> 

# Convert columns to appropriate types if necessary
gapminder <- gapminder %>%
  mutate(
    year = as.integer(year),
    life_expectancy = as.numeric(life_expectancy),
    population_millions = as.numeric(population_millions),
    gdp_per_capita = as.numeric(gdp_per_capita)
  )

# Create a scatter plot of life expectancy vs. population,
# with different colors representing continents.
ggplot(gapminder, aes(x = population_millions, y = life_expectancy, color = continent)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.6) +  # Add points with some transparency
  labs(
    x = "Population (millions)",
    y = "Life Expectancy",
    color = "Continent"
  ) +
  theme_minimal()  # Use a minimal theme for clarity

title: Gapminder Dataset Website
text:
Welcome to the Gapminder Dataset Website
The Gapminder dataset contains statistics for 142 countries from 1952 to 2007 (recorded every 5 years). The data includes life expectancy, population (in millions), and GDP per capita.

Life Expectancy and GDP per Capita 
Life Expectancy and Population 
Country Analysis

title: Country Analysis
text:
Country Analysis
This page analyzes the trends of life expectancy, GDP per capita, and population for a specific country over time. In this example, we focus on data from China.

# Load required libraries
library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)


Attaching package: 'dplyr'


The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':

    filter, lag


The following objects are masked from 'package:base':

    intersect, setdiff, setequal, union

library(readr)
library(gridExtra)  # For arranging multiple plots


Attaching package: 'gridExtra'


The following object is masked from 'package:dplyr':

    combine

# Read the CSV file using read_csv
gapminder <- read_csv("D:/QTM530/qtm350-quiz02/gapminder.csv")

Rows: 1704 Columns: 6


── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr (2): country, continent
dbl (4): year, life_expectancy, population_millions, gdp_per_capita

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

# Inspect the data structure
str(gapminder)

spc_tbl_ [1,704 × 6] (S3: spec_tbl_df/tbl_df/tbl/data.frame)
 $ country            : chr [1:1704] "Afghanistan" "Afghanistan" "Afghanistan" "Afghanistan" ...
 $ continent          : chr [1:1704] "Asia" "Asia" "Asia" "Asia" ...
 $ year               : num [1:1704] 1952 1957 1962 1967 1972 ...
 $ life_expectancy    : num [1:1704] 28.8 30.3 32 34 36.1 ...
 $ population_millions: num [1:1704] 8.43 9.24 10.27 11.54 13.08 ...
 $ gdp_per_capita     : num [1:1704] 779 821 853 836 740 ...
 - attr(*, "spec")=
  .. cols(
  ..   country = col_character(),
  ..   continent = col_character(),
  ..   year = col_double(),
  ..   life_expectancy = col_double(),
  ..   population_millions = col_double(),
  ..   gdp_per_capita = col_double()
  .. )
 - attr(*, "problems")=<externalptr> 

# Convert columns to appropriate types if necessary
gapminder <- gapminder %>%
  mutate(
    year = as.integer(year),
    life_expectancy = as.numeric(life_expectancy),
    population_millions = as.numeric(population_millions),
    gdp_per_capita = as.numeric(gdp_per_capita)
  )

# Filter data for the specific country (e.g., China)
country_data <- gapminder %>% filter(country == "China")

# Plot 1: Life Expectancy over Time
p1 <- ggplot(country_data, aes(x = year, y = life_expectancy)) +
  geom_line(color = "blue") +
  geom_point(color = "blue") +
  labs(title = "Life Expectancy Trend", x = "Year", y = "Life Expectancy") +
  theme_minimal()

# Plot 2: GDP per Capita over Time
p2 <- ggplot(country_data, aes(x = year, y = gdp_per_capita)) +
  geom_line(color = "green") +
  geom_point(color = "green") +
  labs(title = "GDP per Capita Trend", x = "Year", y = "GDP per Capita") +
  theme_minimal()

# Plot 3: Population over Time
p3 <- ggplot(country_data, aes(x = year, y = population_millions)) +
  geom_line(color = "red") +
  geom_point(color = "red") +
  labs(title = "Population Trend", x = "Year", y = "Population (millions)") +
  theme_minimal()

# Arrange the three plots vertically
grid.arrange(p1, p2, p3, ncol = 1)

title: Create the Gapminder dataset
text:
# Import necessary libraries
import pandas as pd
from gapminder import gapminder

# Rename 'lifeExp' to 'life_expectancy' and 'gdpPercap' to 'gdp_per_capita'
gapminder = gapminder.rename(columns={'lifeExp': 'life_expectancy',
                                      'pop': 'population_millions', 
                                      'gdpPercap': 'gdp_per_capita'})

# Convert population to millions
gapminder['population_millions'] = gapminder['population_millions'] / 1_000_000

# Create a new pandas DataFrame from the modified gapminder data
gapminder_df = pd.DataFrame(gapminder)

# Save the DataFrame as a CSV file
gapminder_df.to_csv('gapminder.csv', index=False)

# Print the first 3 rows of the DataFrame
print(gapminder_df.head(3))

       country continent  year  life_expectancy  population_millions  \
0  Afghanistan      Asia  1952           28.801             8.425333   
1  Afghanistan      Asia  1957           30.332             9.240934   
2  Afghanistan      Asia  1962           31.997            10.267083   

   gdp_per_capita  
0      779.445314  
1      820.853030  
2      853.100710

title: Life Expectancy and GDP per Capita
text:
Life Expectancy and GDP per Capita
This page demonstrates the relationship between life expectancy and GDP per capita. The plot below uses a logarithmic scale for GDP per capita to better display the data, with different colors representing different years.

# Load necessary libraries
library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)


Attaching package: 'dplyr'


The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':

    filter, lag


The following objects are masked from 'package:base':

    intersect, setdiff, setequal, union

library(readr)

# Read the CSV file using read_csv for robust type inference
# Replace the path below with your actual path if needed
gapminder <- read_csv("D:/QTM530/qtm350-quiz02/gapminder.csv")

Rows: 1704 Columns: 6


── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr (2): country, continent
dbl (4): year, life_expectancy, population_millions, gdp_per_capita

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

# Inspect the structure of the dataset to check column types
str(gapminder)

spc_tbl_ [1,704 × 6] (S3: spec_tbl_df/tbl_df/tbl/data.frame)
 $ country            : chr [1:1704] "Afghanistan" "Afghanistan" "Afghanistan" "Afghanistan" ...
 $ continent          : chr [1:1704] "Asia" "Asia" "Asia" "Asia" ...
 $ year               : num [1:1704] 1952 1957 1962 1967 1972 ...
 $ life_expectancy    : num [1:1704] 28.8 30.3 32 34 36.1 ...
 $ population_millions: num [1:1704] 8.43 9.24 10.27 11.54 13.08 ...
 $ gdp_per_capita     : num [1:1704] 779 821 853 836 740 ...
 - attr(*, "spec")=
  .. cols(
  ..   country = col_character(),
  ..   continent = col_character(),
  ..   year = col_double(),
  ..   life_expectancy = col_double(),
  ..   population_millions = col_double(),
  ..   gdp_per_capita = col_double()
  .. )
 - attr(*, "problems")=<externalptr> 

# Convert columns to appropriate types if necessary
# This step ensures that numeric and integer columns are correctly typed
gapminder <- gapminder %>%
  mutate(
    year = as.integer(year),
    life_expectancy = as.numeric(life_expectancy),
    population_millions = as.numeric(population_millions),
    gdp_per_capita = as.numeric(gdp_per_capita)
  )

# Create a scatter plot with a logarithmic scale for the GDP per capita axis
ggplot(gapminder, aes(x = gdp_per_capita, y = life_expectancy, color = factor(year))) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.6) +       # Add points with transparency
  scale_x_log10() +               # Apply log scale to GDP per capita axis
  labs(
    x = "GDP per Capita (log scale)",
    y = "Life Expectancy",
    color = "Year"
  ) +
  theme_minimal()                 # Use a minimal theme for a clean look
